name: Hikaru Utada
description:
{{Nihongo|'''Hikaru Utada'''|宇多田ヒカル|Utada Hikaru|born January 19, 1983}}, also known [[mononym]]ously as '''Utada''', is a Japanese and American  singer, songwriter, and record producer. They{{Efn|Utada uses ''[[they/them]]'' and ''[[she/her]]'' pronouns.<ref name="instagram.com">{{cite web |url=https://www.instagram.com/kuma_power/ |title=Hikaru Utada's Instagram Profile |website=[[Instagram]] |archive-url=https://archive.today/20220416042058/https://www.instagram.com/kuma_power/ |archive-date=April 16, 2022 |url-status=live |access-date=June 17, 2022 |language=en }}</ref> This article uses ''they/them'' for consistency.|name=pronouns|group=lower-alpha}}  are considered to be one of the most influential and best-selling musical artists in Japan. They are perhaps best known by international audiences for writing and performing four theme-songs to [[Square Enix]] and [[Disney Interactive Studios|Disney]]'s ''[[Kingdom Hearts]]'' video game series: "[[Simple and Clean]]", "[[Passion (Hikaru Utada song)|Sanctuary]]", "[[Chikai (Hikaru Utada song)|Don't Think Twice]]", and "[[Face My Fears]]" (with [[Skrillex]]).

Utada was born in New York City to Japanese parents, record producer [[Teruzane Utada]] and {{lang|ja-Latn|[[enka]]}} singer [[Keiko Fuji]]. They began to write songs at an early age and often traveled to Tokyo as a result of their father's job. Adopting the stage name '''Cubic U''', they signed with [[Toshiba-EMI]] to release their English-language debut album, ''[[Precious (Cubic U album)|Precious]]'' (1998). Released the following year, their second album and Japanese-language debut, ''[[First Love (Hikaru Utada album)|First Love]]'' (1999), leaned further into R&B and dance-pop influences; it was a commercial success, becoming Japan's [[List of best-selling albums in Japan|best-selling album]] of all time. Its singles "[[Automatic (Hikaru Utada song)|Automatic]]", "[[Time Will Tell (Hikaru Utada song)|Time Will Tell]]", and "[[Movin' On Without You]]" were commercially successful, while the album sold two million units in its first week in Japan, topped the [[Oricon]] chart for six non-consecutive weeks, and sold six million more units throughout the rest of 1999.

Utada's third album ''[[Distance (Hikaru Utada album)|Distance]]'' was released in early 2001 and spawned their biggest singles—"[[Addicted to You (Hikaru Utada song)|Addicted to You]]", "[[Wait & See (Risk)]]" and "[[Can You Keep a Secret? (song)|Can You Keep a Secret?]]" — each of which received multi-platinum certifications in Japan and other countries; it broke several sales records after three million copies were sold in its first week, instantly becoming Japan's [[Lists of fastest-selling albums#Japan|fastest-selling album]]. Her fourth album, ''[[Deep River (Hikaru Utada album)|Deep River]]'' (2002)—backed by chart-topping singles such as "[[Traveling (song)|Traveling]]", "[[Hikari (Hikaru Utada song)|Hikari]]" and "[[Sakura Drops]]"—incorporated elements of pop folk, and became one of Japan's top-selling records of all time. Their subsequent albums, ''[[Exodus (Hikaru Utada album)|Exodus]]'' (2004), ''[[Ultra Blue]]'' (2006) and ''[[Heart Station]]'' (2008), also sold millions of copies. After a prolonged hiatus, Utada released the acoustic-driven albums ''[[Fantôme (album)|Fantôme]]'' (2016) and ''[[Hatsukoi (Hikaru Utada album)|Hatsukoi]]'' (2018), which reached number one on the Oricon albums chart. They topped the charts again with 2022's ''[[Bad Mode]]'', their first Japanese/English album.

By the end of the 2000s, Utada was deemed "the most influential artist of the decade" in the Japanese music landscape by ''[[The Japan Times]]''. They are one of Japan's [[List of best-selling music artists in Japan|top-selling recording artists]] of all time with over 40 million records sold. Twelve of their singles have reached number one on the [[Oricon Singles Chart]], while ten albums have become chart-toppers. Six of their full-length releases are among Japan's highest-selling albums, including ''First Love'', ''Distance'' and ''Deep River'', which are among the top ten best-selling records of Japan's music history. In 2021, Utada became one of the first Japanese figures to publicly identify as [[non-binary]].
